Yes, submarine crews receive extensive training on how to deal with the stress of being on a submarine for extended periods of time. This training is referred to as "submarine psychology" and covers topics such as managing stress, maintaining mental health, and dealing with isolation and confinement.

Submarine crews receive initial training in submarine psychology during their basic training, and continuation training is provided throughout their careers. During this training, crew members are taught to recognize the signs and symptoms of stress and mental health issues, and they are taught techniques for managing stress and maintaining their mental health. Crew members also learn how to recognize signs of mental health issues in their fellow crew members and how to support and assist them in seeking help if needed.

In addition to training, submarine crews have access to mental health resources such as counseling, therapy, and mental health providers. The Navy recognizes the unique stressors and challenges faced by submariners and provides specialized support to help them maintain their mental health and well-being.

Overall, submarine crews receive extensive training on how to deal with the stress of being on a submarine for extended periods of time and are provided with resources and support to help them maintain their mental health and well-being.
